intro: Angelica pachyptera, commonly known as the thick-leaf angelica, is a perennial herb native to the mountainous regions of Central Asia. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its tall, branched stem and large, pinnately compound leaves. The plant produces small, greenish-yellow flowers arranged in umbels, which bloom in summer. Its roots are thick and fleshy, often used in traditional medicine for their purported health benefits. Angelica pachyptera thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in alpine meadows.
